extractions.description: This paper explores the application of transformers in reinforcement learning, discussing how they address traditional challenges in RL, including unstable training and partial observability. The paper provides a comprehensive survey of how transformers are used in different RL tasks, such as representation learning, transition and reward function modeling, and policy optimization. It also examines recent research efforts to improve transformers' interpretability and efficiency in RL.

title.value: Transformers in Reinforcement Learning: A Survey
title.justification: The title is explicit and encapsulates the central theme of the paper, which is a survey of the application of transformers in RL.
title.quote: Transformers in Reinforcement Learning: A Survey

type.justification: The paper surveys multiple transformer applications in RL, discussing empirical results from various studies that highlight their performance and limitations.
type.quote: This document surveys the use of transformers in RL... We highlight challenges that classical RL approaches face and how transformers can help deal with these challenges.

research_field.justification: The paper deals extensively with machine learning techniques, specifically focusing on the intersection of transformers and reinforcement learning.
research_field.quote: Transformers have significantly impacted domains like natural language processing, computer vision, and robotics... This survey explores how transformers are used in reinforcement learning.

sub_research_field.justification: The paper focuses specifically on the use of transformers to enhance various aspects of reinforcement learning.

name.justification: The Decision Transformer is introduced as an approach for offline RL using transformers.
name.quote: The decision transformer (DT) [23] is an offline RL method that uses the upside-down RL paradigm... It uses a transformer-decoder to predict actions conditioned on past states, past actions, and expected return-to-go.

type.justification: The Decision Transformer is a specific architecture that applies transformer models to RL tasks.
type.quote: The decision transformer (DT) [23] is an offline RL method that uses the upside-down RL paradigm.

name.justification: The Trajectory Transformer is presented as a method to plan future actions by modeling past states, actions, and rewards.
name.quote: The trajectory transformer (TT) [69], an MBRL approach that formulates RL as a conditional sequence modeling problem. TT models past states, actions, and rewards to predict future actions, states, and rewards effectively.

type.justification: The Trajectory Transformer applies transformers for modeling sequences in RL to plan actions.
type.quote: The trajectory transformer (TT) [69], an MBRL approach that formulates RL as a conditional sequence modeling problem.

name.justification: It is mentioned as a paradigm used within RL to process sequences and map them to actions.
name.quote: The decision transformer (DT) [23] is an offline RL method that uses the upside-down RL paradigm.

type.justification: Upside Down RL is a conceptual framework rather than an exact model but is relevant in the context of transformers.
type.quote: Upside-Down RL flips the traditional RL paradigm and uses the desired return (g), the horizon (h), and the state as inputs.

name.justification: GTrXL is described as a transformer variant tailored to improve training stability in RL.
name.quote: The gated transformer-XL (GTrXL) architecture [140] has demonstrated promising results in stabilizing RL training and improving performance.

type.justification: GTrXL is a variant of the transformer model specifically designed to enhance RL tasks.
type.quote: The gated transformer-XL (GTrXL) architecture [140] has demonstrated promising results in stabilizing RL training and improving performance.

name.quote: Empirical experiments demonstrate that the DT outperforms state-of-the-art model-free offline approaches on offline datasets such as Atari and Key-to-Door tasks.

name.quote: Empirical experiments demonstrate that the DT outperforms state-of-the-art model-free offline approaches on offline datasets such as Atari and Key-to-Door tasks.
